item.description:
Though every hike is poetry; There is no verse without friends.

Need I Say More???

At first it's a mere walk in the woods, nothing too difficult, nothing too hard, such a walk that you might say is straight from your own backyard. But in your haste, you'll learn you've spoken out of place, because within an hour or two, you just might stammer, as this mere walk as I have called it, has turned into a very strenuous clamber.

About The Hike

It all begins as we wind our way north along the Whitehouse Trail, skirting the Pemi Bike Path until we can skirt no more… that is, until we reach the Liberty Spring Trail. Once on Liberty Spring, we’ll follow the path as it leads us deeper and deeper into the forest, further and further into the woods, deeper as it curves its way thru sinewy hardwood, and further as it guides us past bristly pine. In route, we’ll bear left, by-passing the Flume Slide Trail (0.6 miles), hop, skip and jump over a stream or two, before enduring the final push, the final vertiginous rise to the Liberty Spring Tentsite (2.6 miles) and Franconia Ridge Trail (2.9 miles).

Once we reach the ridge, we’ll turn right on to the FRT and climb the next 0.8 miles south to the cragged rock of Liberty’s summit. From Liberty, we’ll descend, steeply at first, and then pass thru two small sags before rising to the open summit of Mt. Flume, 1.1 miles later. It is at this point we will turn around and retrace our steps back to our cars by way of butt, sled or sole.

Note: We'll be paying close attention to weather and trail conditions, and should there be any adverse weather, such as high winds at the summit or an approaching storm, or should trail conditions prove to be more difficult than anticipated, it may be necessary for us to avoid the summits, alter our plans, and/or cancel the hike altogether.

EQUIPMENT CHECKLIST
(gear must be winter weather tested)

Cold Weather/Winter Essentials (required):
• Synthetic or Wool Wicking Underpant & Undershirt
• Mid-layer Synthetic or Wool Insulating Pant & Shirt
• Insulated/Fleece Jacket and/or Vest
• Windproof/Waterproof Shell w/hood & Pant
• Synthetic or Wool Sock Liners (wicking layer)
• Synthetic or Wool Socks (insulating layer)
• Sturdy Hiking Boots (waterproof & insulated)
• Hat & Gloves
• Balaclava
• Goggles
• Extra Insulating Layers (pant & top)
• Extra pair of Socks, Hat & Gloves
• Water (min. 2L) - in a wide-mouthed bottle
• Lunch
• Snack/Energy Food (extra food)
• Map/Compass/Whistle
• Headlamp/Flashlight (w/ fresh lithium batteries)
• Emergency Blanket (so small & light, there's no reason not to carry one)
• MICROspikes or mountaineering crampons
• Snowshoes
• Gaiters

the Remaining Essentials:
• Medication/First Aid Supplies*
• Hand Warmers
• Sleeping Bag & Pad*
• Light-weight Emergency Shelter/Bivy*
• Stove*
• Fire (waterproof matches, lighter, starter)
• Repair Kit/Knife

Optional:
• Sunscreen/Sunglasses/Bug Repellent/Toiletries
• Trekking Poles (very helpful when using snowshoes; very helpful when not using snowshoes)
• Camera/Binoculars

* To Be Carried Among The Group

LET'S NOT UNDERESTIMATE ANYTHING; come prepared for the worst... cold-cold temps., snowy-snowy weather, darkness and lots of wind.
ALSO... TAKE NOTE: the "Optional" list is significantly smaller than at any other time of year.

Annnd... seeing that we'll most likely encounter open flowing water, please make sure you have an extra pair of socks and a second pair of pants should there be an unforeseen fall into the drink.

 

Directions

From points south, follow I-93N to Exit 34A (approx. 4 miles past the Lincoln/Kancamagus Hwy exit). Bearing right, merge with Route 3N toward the Flume Gorge Visitor Center; follow the Daniel Webster Hwy (Rt 3) for approx. 3/4 of a mile. The parking lot is on your right, approximately 1/4 mile past the Flume Gorge Visitor Center. Look for the "Trailhead Parking" sign.

From the north, follow I-93S to Exit 34A. Follow Route 3S for approximately 3/4 of a mile, turning left into the parking lot marked Trailhead Parking*. Should you reach the Flume Gorge Visitor Center, turn around; the parking lot is approximately 1/4 mile north of the Center. Look for the "Trailhead Parking" sign.

Google Maps: http://maps.google.com/maps...
Coordinates: 44.099701, -71.682524

* It is also referred to as the Hiker's Lot.


 

Additional Information

Mount Liberty: 4459 feet
Mount Flume: 4328 feet
Total elevation gain: approx. 4250 feet

Distance from Whitehouse Trailhead to Mt Liberty: 4.0 miles
Distance from Mt Liberty to Mt Flume: 1.1 miles
Total distance (round trip): 10.2 miles

Exposure: Moderate/Full
Difficulty: Strenuous
Pace: Moderate

Sunrise: 6:57 AM
Sunset: 6:54 PM

Approx. High Temp: Cold
Approx. Low Temp: Really Cold

Extended AccuWeather Forecast:
http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/lincoln-nh/03251/daily-weather-forecast/2174585

7-Day National Weather Forecast (NOAA):
http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php...

6-Day Mountain-Forecast.com:
http://www.mountain-forecast.com/peaks/Mount-Liberty-New-Hampshire/forecasts/1359

Mt. Washington Observatory Higher Summits Forecast:
http://www.mountwashington.org/weather/summit_forecast.php

Weather & Trail Conditions (AMC):
http://www.outdoors.org/recreation/tripplanner/go/backcountry-weather.cfm

Weather & Trail Conditions (TrailsNH):
http://trailsnh.com/New-Hampshire-4000-Footers.php


Liability Waiver

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at www.hikesafe.com; the leader(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify the leader(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
item.how_to_find_us: IMPORTANT!! Parking is located 1/4 mile past the Flume Gorge Visitor Center (44.099701, -71.682524) as you travel north on Rt 3 (or before, if you're headed south); Cell: 860-460-1500
item.name: Liberty & Flume
